etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in William Wood (fl. 1629–1635), writer on America. From Narragansett nókehick and its cognate Massachusett nookhik nocake, lit. ‘thing pounded soft’ (in the Bible translating ‘meal’, ‘flour’, ‘ground corn’)

definitions: Maize which is parched and pounded into meal, used as an article of food. Compare "rokeag", yokeag.
